intent.oneSentence: Give complete beginners a safe, practical “taste of the Agile ocean” so they can start operating as a Scrum Master: run core Scrum events well, protect focus and quality, handle common team/stakeholder failure modes, and earn an Amanoba certificate as proof of mastery.
outcomes: Explain the Scrum Master role in practice (what you do, what you don’t do) and avoid common anti-patterns (project manager, secretary, police).
Run Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Retrospective with clear goals, timeboxes, and concrete outputs.
Create a beginner-safe team operating pack: Working Agreement, Definition of Done (v0.1), and a minimal metric starter set.
Diagnose and intervene in common situations: chaotic dailies, scope pressure, conflict between PO and Developers, and lack of focus due to high WIP.
Use facilitation and coaching basics: define meeting outcomes, ask better questions, and turn debates into experiments.
Complete the course and pass the final exam to earn a shareable Amanoba certificate (track record).
nonGoals: Not a guarantee for external certifications (PSM/CSM) or job placement.
Not deep specialization in scaling frameworks (SAFe/LeSS) beyond context and decision signals.
Not a tool tutorial for Jira/Linear/etc.; tools are treated as interchangeable patterns.

bannedPatterns: references to the lesson instead of stating the scenario (e.g. “as described in the lesson”)
title-based crutches (repeating the lesson title instead of testing a decision)
options that are too short to be educational

Agile.definition: A mindset and set of principles focused on delivering value through feedback, learning, and adaptation under uncertainty.
notes: Agile is not “faster”; it is better learning and decision-making under change.

Scrum.definition: A lightweight framework to solve complex problems by delivering value iteratively using roles, events, and artifacts.
notes: Scrum is a container for empiricism: transparency, inspection, adaptation.

ScrumMasterRole.definition: A servant-leader who enables Scrum by coaching, facilitating, removing impediments, and protecting the team’s ability to deliver value.
notes: The Scrum Master does not own product decisions; they enable the system.

Empiricism.definition: Working based on evidence and feedback loops: transparency → inspection → adaptation.
notes: If you can’t inspect reality, you can’t improve it.

PsychologicalSafety.definition: A team climate where people can speak up, admit uncertainty, and learn without fear.
notes: Without safety, you get silence, politics, and fake agreement.

WorkingAgreement.definition: A written agreement describing how the team collaborates (norms, communication, decision rules).
notes: It’s a living contract; review it after recurring failures.

DefinitionOfDone.definition: A shared checklist of quality and completion that makes “done” testable and consistent.
notes: A weak DoD creates rework and trust loss.

BacklogItem.definition: A unit of work/value in the Product Backlog that should be understandable, testable, and appropriately sized.
notes: A backlog item is not a vague idea; it must support a decision to deliver.

AcceptanceCriteria.definition: Specific conditions that define when a backlog item is acceptable (testable outcomes and boundaries).
notes: Criteria reduce ambiguity and are a foundation for good Sprint Planning.

SprintGoal.definition: A single coherent objective that guides the sprint and helps trade-offs when scope pressure appears.
notes: Without a goal, every request becomes “urgent” and focus collapses.

WIP.definition: Work in progress: tasks started but not finished; high WIP reduces throughput and increases switching cost.
notes: WIP limits protect flow and focus.

Facilitation.definition: Designing and guiding group conversations toward a clear outcome (decision, plan, or learning).
notes: Facilitation is about outcomes, not speaking time.

CoachingMindset.definition: Helping others think and own solutions through questions, reflection, and feedback instead of giving answers.
notes: Coaching builds capability; solving builds dependency.

Stakeholder.definition: Anyone impacted by the product or influencing its success (customers, leadership, adjacent teams).
notes: Stakeholder pressure is real; the system must channel it without breaking the team.

Experiment.definition: A timeboxed change with a hypothesis and measurement to learn what improves outcomes.
notes: Turn debates into experiments when opinions have no data.

FlowMetrics.definition: A minimal set of measures to see flow, quality, and value (not vanity).
notes: Bad metrics create gaming; good metrics create learning.

procedures.name: Role boundaries: what you do vs what you don’t
steps: Name the request and who owns the decision (PO/Developers/Stakeholder).
Translate the request into a process improvement or facilitation need.
Offer a next step that keeps ownership in the right place (questions, agenda, decision rule).

procedures.name: Sprint Planning agenda (goal → forecast → risks → commitment language)
steps: State purpose and timebox; confirm what ‘done’ means (DoD).
Draft a Sprint Goal statement (one sentence).
Select items based on goal; clarify acceptance criteria and risks.
Confirm capacity and WIP; agree on the first 24 hours plan.
Close with: what is the goal, what is included, what is excluded.

procedures.name: Daily Scrum as an impediment-focused reset
steps: Restate the Sprint Goal and today’s most important outcomes.
Surface blockers and dependencies first (not status).
Agree on 1–3 coordination decisions (who talks to whom, by when).
Close with a WIP check and a 24-hour focus commitment.

procedures.name: Sprint Review for value and learning
steps: Open with goal and what was intended to learn/deliver.
Demo working outcomes; capture stakeholder feedback as decisions/next options.
Separate requests into now/next/later; protect sprint boundaries.
Close with a 3-item summary: value delivered, feedback learned, next direction.

procedures.name: Retrospective: from complaint to measurable action
steps: Pick one theme (avoid ‘everything’).
Find a root cause (5 Whys or simple cause map).
Define one action: owner + due date + metric/observable signal.
Plan a follow-up check (next retro).

procedures.name: WIP policy: limit, reset, and enforce
steps: Define WIP limit per person/team lane.
Define stop-start rules when limit is exceeded.
Review weekly: what improved, what broke, adjust limit.

procedures.name: Conflict mediation: position → interest → next experiment
steps: Restate both positions neutrally.
Extract interests/constraints (why each side cares).
Define a decision rule (data, cost, risk, time).
If no data: propose a timeboxed experiment with metric.

procedures.name: Metrics starter pack: flow + quality + value
steps: Pick 1 flow metric, 1 quality metric, 1 value metric, and 1 health metric.
Define what good looks like (directional targets, not vanity).
Decide review cadence and who owns each metric.
Write a rule: what action you take if metric worsens.

procedures.name: Introduce a new team habit as a 2-week experiment
steps: Name the problem symptom and the intended outcome.
Write a hypothesis: ‘If we do X, we expect Y because Z’.
Define a simple measurement and a review date.
Run for 2 weeks, then keep/change/stop based on evidence.

application: Given a team scenario, choose the best Scrum Master next action that preserves ownership and improves flow.
Pick the correct meeting goal/agenda element for the situation (Planning/Daily/Review/Retro).
Diagnose a failure mode (e.g. chaotic daily, high WIP, scope pressure) and select a concrete intervention rule.
Choose the best artifact improvement (DoD/Working Agreement/Acceptance Criteria) to fix the described issue.
Convert a debate into an experiment with hypothesis and metric.
criticalThinking: Trade-off: protect sprint goal vs accept urgent request; justify decision rule.
Second-order effects: predict what happens if you implement a ‘fix’ poorly (e.g. metrics as KPI).
System design: propose a minimal operating pack for a new team and define governance/check cadence.

distractorGuidelines: Wrong options must be plausible and aligned with common Scrum anti-patterns (micromanagement, meeting theater, blame).
Avoid ‘none of the above’ and avoid throwaway answers; each distractor should represent a realistic mistake.
Options must be specific enough to teach why they are wrong.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Scrum Master 2026: role, boundaries, and impact
lessons.intent: Create a beginner-safe mental model for the role and prevent PM/secretary anti-patterns.
goals: Describe the Scrum Master’s job in practice.
List what you do not own (product and technical decisions).
Recognize 3 anti-patterns and the right response.
commonMistakes: Acting as a project manager and owning scope decisions.
Turning the role into meeting scheduling only.
Becoming ‘process police’ instead of enabling outcomes.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Agile vs Scrum: what you’re tasting in this course
lessons.intent: Position Scrum inside Agile and clarify what matters for beginners.
goals: Differentiate Agile mindset from Scrum framework.
commonMistakes: Treating Agile as speed instead of learning.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Scrum overview: roles, events, artifacts, and outputs
lessons.intent: Build a one-page working map of Scrum to reduce confusion later.
goals: Name the purpose and output of each event.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Team as a system: safety, focus, and rules
lessons.intent: Introduce team dynamics and safety as prerequisites for honest inspection.
goals: Write 3 simple team rules that increase safety.
commonMistakes: Allowing one voice to dominate decisions.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Definition of Done v0.1: quality as a gate
lessons.intent: Teach ‘done’ as testable quality, not a feeling; create DoD starter.
goals: Identify a DoD failure mode in a scenario.
commonMistakes: Allowing exceptions that become the norm.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Backlog basics: value, risk, and acceptance criteria
lessons.intent: Make backlog items understandable and testable so planning works.
goals: Define a minimum backlog item card.
Write acceptance criteria for a vague request.
Spot ambiguity and ask clarifying questions.
commonMistakes: Accepting ‘just do it’ requests without criteria.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Refinement taste: prepare planning with clarity and sizing
lessons.intent: Introduce refinement as risk reduction and clarity building.
goals: Split one large item into smaller deliverables.
commonMistakes: Skipping refinement and paying the cost in planning.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Sprint Planning: goal, forecast, and commitment language
lessons.intent: Teach planning outcomes and how to protect focus via sprint goal.
goals: Select items based on the goal.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Daily Scrum without status theater: impediments and coordination
lessons.intent: Turn daily into a short reset that drives coordination and focus.
commonMistakes: Daily becomes reporting to a manager.
No decisions are made; only talking.

lessons.canonicalTitle: WIP and focus: why parallel work kills throughput
lessons.intent: Teach WIP as the easiest beginner leverage point to improve delivery.
goals: Apply stop-start when the limit is exceeded.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Facilitation basics: outcomes, timeboxes, and decision rules
lessons.intent: Give facilitation fundamentals to prevent endless meetings.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Sprint Review: value demonstration and feedback capture
lessons.intent: Teach review as learning with stakeholders and future direction.
goals: Protect sprint boundaries while staying responsive.
commonMistakes: Feedback becomes scope creep without triage.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Retrospective: measurable improvement instead of complaint loops
lessons.intent: Teach retro as one actionable improvement with ownership and measure.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Conflict patterns: PO vs Developers vs Stakeholders
lessons.intent: Prepare beginners to mediate conflict and protect ownership boundaries.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Decision vs experiment: how to end endless debates
lessons.intent: Teach a simple move: convert opinion wars into experiments.
goals: Define a metric and review date.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Metrics starter pack: flow + quality + value + health
lessons.intent: Introduce minimal metrics to see reality without gaming.
goals: Define what action to take when it worsens.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Coaching mindset: questions over answers
lessons.intent: Shift from ‘fixing’ to building team capability and ownership.
commonMistakes: Creating dependency on the Scrum Master.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Stakeholder management: expectations and communication cadence
lessons.intent: Teach predictable communication to reduce chaos and interruptions.
commonMistakes: Allowing stakeholders to bypass the system.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Change management: introduce a habit as a 2-week experiment
lessons.intent: Make change safe by timeboxing and measuring outcomes.
commonMistakes: Rolling out change as a command.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Remote/hybrid Scrum: focus and meeting hygiene
lessons.intent: Adapt the system to remote realities (energy, attention, time zones).
commonMistakes: Meetings that drag with no engagement.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Scaling taste: when scaling helps and when it hurts
lessons.intent: Give context signals for scaling without deep framework teaching.
commonMistakes: SAFe as a fix for basic hygiene problems.

lessons.canonicalTitle: IT vs non-IT Scrum: what changes, what stays
lessons.intent: Help beginners transfer Scrum patterns beyond software context.
goals: Define acceptance criteria in non-IT context.
commonMistakes: Using ‘we’re not IT’ as an excuse.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Risk and uncertainty: spikes, discovery, prototypes
lessons.intent: Teach safe moves for unknowns without pretending certainty.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Quality and technical practices taste: what a Scrum Master must ask
lessons.intent: Give non-technical beginners the right questions to protect quality.
goals: Define a DoD improvement question list.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Tools and workflow hygiene: boards that reflect reality
lessons.intent: Teach board hygiene and policies that support flow, not cosmetics.
goals: Use WIP policy on the board.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Career map: junior → mid → senior Scrum Master
lessons.intent: Make progression measurable: impact, not admin work.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Interview taste: question patterns and answer structure
lessons.intent: Prepare beginners to speak in concrete interventions and outcomes.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Ethics and boundaries: when to say no
lessons.intent: Protect team integrity; know when to push back on non-Scrum demands.
goals: Offer an alternative that preserves outcomes.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Final exam readiness: scenario patterns you must handle
lessons.intent: Summarize common failure modes and the right intervention moves.
goals: Identify personal weak areas to review.

lessons.canonicalTitle: Your Scrum Master playbook v1 + certificate plan
lessons.intent: Ship a personal playbook and a next-90-days plan; close with proof path.
